Do niszczenia struktur na wiêkszym obszarze bardziej efektywna jest d³u¿ej trwaj¹ca fala uderzeniowa, chocia¿ generowane przez eksploduj¹cy rozpylony materia³ ciœnienie jest ni¿sze. Ponadto du¿¹ zalet¹ mieszanin paliwowo-powietrznych jest mo¿liwoœæ inicjacji wybuchu objêtoœciowego w przestrzeni setek, a nawet tysiêcy metrów szeœciennych, a nie - jak w przypadku skondensowanych materia³ów wybuchowych - u³amka metra szeœciennego. Bomba paliwowo-powietrzna zawieraj¹ca 100 kg materia³u wybuchowego generuje energiê porównywalna z eksplozj¹ 1200 kg trotylu. Skutecznoœæ ra¿enia bomb tego typu jest bardzo wysoka i przewy¿sza 3-5 razy skutecznoœæ ra¿enia bomb takiej samej wagi i wielkoœci z ³adunkiem trotylowym.
TEXT.Russian: Пушка Гаусса - это тип ускорителя снарядов, состоящий из одной или нескольких катушек, используемых в качестве электромагнитов в конфигурации линейного двигателя, ускоряющие ферромагнитный или проводящий снаряд до высокой скорости. Практически во всех конфигурациях койлганов катушки и ствол ружья расположены на общей оси.

TEXT.English: In Greek mythology, Theseus was a son of either King Aegeus or Poseidon. Before Aegeus left Troezen he placed his sword and sandals beneath a huge rock and told his wife Aethra that when their son, Theseus, could lift the rock he was to bring the gifts to his kingdom in Athens. At the age of 16 Theseus lifted the rock and began his journey, during which he freed the countryside of various monsters and villains (e.g., Procrustes). When Theseus arrived at Athens, Medea, then wife of Aegeus, tried to kill him. Aegeus, however, recognized the sword and sandals, saved Theseus, and exiled Medea. Theseus subsequently had numerous adventures. His most famous exploit was against the Minotaur of King Minos of Crete. Theseus insisted on being one of the seven youths and seven maidens of Athens to be sacrificed to the monster as an annual tribute. He promised his father that if he were successful in killing the Minotaur he would on his return voyage replace his ship's black sails with white ones. Ariadne, daughter of King Minos, fell in love with Theseus and gave him a magic ball of thread to be dropped at the entrance of the labyrinth; it led Theseus to the Minotaur, which he killed, and he then followed the unwound thread back to the entrance. He left Crete with Ariadne but abandoned her at Naxos. When Theseus reached home he forgot to raise white sails. Aegeus saw black sails, and, thinking his son dead, the grief-stricken father threw himself into the sea, thereafter called the Aegean. As king of Athens, Theseus instituted several reforms, most notably the federalization of the scattered Attic communities. He journeyed to the land of the Amazons, where he abducted Antiope, who bore him Hippolytus. A vengeful Amazon army invaded Athens, but Theseus defeated it. Some say Antiope died fighting beside him in the battle; others claim that Theseus killed her when she objected to his marriage to Phaedra. For helping Pirithoüs to carry off Persephone, Theseus was imprisoned in Hades until Hercules rescued him. Upon his return to Athens, he found his once great kingdom a turmoil of corruption and rebellion. He regretfully sailed away and came to rest at Skyros, where he was treacherously murdered by King Lycomedes. Although Theseus is generally thought of as legendary, the Athenians believed he had been one of their early kings.
TEXT.Polish: Tezeusz, Theseus (mitologia grecka), heros ateñski, syn króla Egeusza i królowej Ajtry, córki Pitteusa, w³adcy Trojdzeny (w innej wersji Ajtry i boga Posejdona). Tezeusz do 16. roku ¿ycia przebywa³ na dworze swego dziadka. Gdy zmê¿nia³ na tyle, aby podnieœæ g³az, pod którym Pitteus ukry³ miecz i sanda³y, uda³ siê do Aten. W czasie wêdrówki uwalnia³ kraj od potworów i z³oczyñców (Skiron, Prokrust). W Atenach, na skutek intryg Medei, musia³ stoczyæ walkê z bykiem pustosz¹cym pola Maratonu. Poznany przez ojca po mieczu, unikn¹³ trucizny. Wyruszy³ na Kretê w grupie m³odzie¿y stanowi¹cej haracz dla Minotaura, którego pokona³ przy pomocy Ariadny. Zasiada³ na tronie w Atenach, bra³ udzia³ w polowaniu na dzika kalidoñskiego, wyprawie Argonautów, wyprawie po pas Hippolity - uprowadzi³ wtedy Amazonkê Antiope, któr¹ póŸniej porzuci³ dla Fedry, walczy³ z centaurami na weselu Pejritoosa, wtargn¹³ do Hadesu po Persefonê. Zgin¹³ na Skyros, str¹cony podstêpnie ze ska³y przez króla Likomedesa. Ateñczycy przypisywali Tezeuszowi szereg faktów historycznych (zjednoczenie gmin attyckich, ustanowienie Panatenajów, reformy ustrojowe o cechach demokratycznych, podbój Megary, igrzyska istmijskie ku czci Posejdona). W 475 p.n.e. Kimon nakaza³ sprowadziæ ze Skyros prochy Tezeusza. Sanktuarium Tezeusza by³o miejscem azylu dla niewolników i d³u¿ników.

TEXT.English: Thomas Jefferson was the third President of the United States (18011809), the principal author of the Declaration of Independence (1776), and one of the most influential Founding Fathers for his promotion of the ideals of republicanism in the United States. Major events during his presidency include the Louisiana Purchase (1803) and the Lewis and Clark Expedition (18041806). As a political philosopher, Jefferson was a man of the Enlightenment and knew many intellectual leaders in Britain and France. He idealized the independent yeoman farmer as exemplar of republican virtues, distrusted cities and financiers, and favored states' rights and a strictly limited federal government. Jefferson supported the separation of church and state and was the author of the Virginia Statute for Religious Freedom (1779, 1786). He was the eponym of Jeffersonian democracy and the co-founder and leader of the Democratic-Republican Party, which dominated American politics for a quarter-century. Jefferson served as the wartime Governor of Virginia (17791781), first United States Secretary of State (17891793), and second Vice President (17971801). A polymath, Jefferson achieved distinction as, among other things, a horticulturist, statesman, architect, archaeologist, inventor, and founder of the University of Virginia. To date, Jefferson is the only president to serve two full terms in office without vetoing a single bill of Congress. Jefferson has been consistently ranked by scholars as one of the greatest U.S. presidents.
TEXT.Polish: Thomas Jefferson (ur. 13 kwietnia 1743 w Shadwell w stanie Wirginia, zm. 4 lipca 1826 w Charlottesville)? amerykañski prawnik, dzia³acz niepodleg³oœciowy, archeolog, architekt, trzeci prezydent USA (1801-1809), za³o¿yciel stanowego uniwersytetu University of Virginia. Pochodzi³ z zamo¿nej rodziny o wysokim statusie spo³ecznym.

TEXT.English: The Hoplite was the heavy infantryman of Classical-era Greece. Thorax refers to the breastplate that the Athenian hoplite achieved a superiority by wearing later in the period.
TEXT.French: L'hoplite était l'infanterie lourde de la Grèce classique. Thorax se réfère à la cuirasse que l'hoplite athénien portait et grâce à laquelle il acquit une supériorité plus tard dans la période.
TEXT.Italian: L'oplite costituiva il fante pesante nella Grecia dell'era classica; indossava una corazza toracica che permise agli ateniesi di ottenere una superiorità militare in quel periodo.

TEXT.English: Historically, the Thraikioi Peltastai have been around since the late Bronze Age and are often considered the archetype of the Thraikian warrior, though these Hellenized Peltastai are considerably more heavily armored than their fifth century ancestors. The Thraikioi Peltastai have been plying their deadly trade against Hellenes for as long as any Thraikian or Hellene can remember, and their method of warfare was so effective it was copied by the Hellenes and Makedonians and even mimicked by tribes as distant as the Illyrians. The number of battles and by whom they were used is uncountable. Suffice to say Thraikian peltastai have been used in every major conflict between Hellenic states, and will continue to be used.

Thutmose III was the sixth Pharaoh of the Eighteenth Dynasty. During the first twenty-two years of Thutmose's reign he was co-regent with his aunt, Hatshepsut, who was named the pharaoh. While she is shown first on surviving monuments, both were assigned the usual royal names and insignia and neither is given any obvious seniority over the other. He served as the head of her armies. After her death and his later rise to being the pharaoh of the kingdom, he created the largest empire Egypt had ever seen; no fewer than seventeen campaigns were conducted, and he conquered from Niy in north Syria to the fourth waterfall of the Nile in Nubia. Officially, Thutmose III ruled Egypt for almost fifty-four years, and his reign is usually dated from April 24, 1479 BCE to March 11, 1425 BCE; however, this includes the twenty-two years he was co-regent to Hatshepsut--his stepmother and aunt. During the last two years of his reign he became a coregent again, with his son, Amenhotep II, who would succeed him. Of all the kings of ancient Egypt, Thutmose III is perhaps the one who, for the modern historian, most nearly comes to life. His records, though couched in the boastful and extravagant terms thought befitting a pharaoh's exploits, leave little doubt not only of his ability as a soldier and a statesman but also of his abilities as an athlete and a hunter of lion, wild cattle, and elephant. His statues show a youthful, smooth face with a large, high-bridged nose and pleasantly smiling mouth. His fame lived after him. His name inscribed on countless amulets was thought to bring power and protection to the wearers. A popular hymn celebrating his triumphs became a model for later paeans of victory. In it the god Amon-Re says: I set your glory and the fear of you in all lands, and the terror of you as far as the four supports of the sky... the rulers of all foreign countries are gathered together within thy grasp. I stretch out my hands to bind them for you.
TEXT.Polish: Totmes III, faraon, w³adca staro¿ytnego Egiptu XVIII dynastii, z okresu Nowego Pañstwa. Syn Totmesa II i jednej z jego ¿on Iset (Isis). Panowa³ w latach 1458-1425 p.n.e. Jego poprzedniczk¹ by³a Hatszepsut, córka Totmesa I, a siostra Totmesa II. Zatem Hatszepsut by³a jednoczeœnie ciotk¹, macoch¹ i teœciow¹ Totmesa. Ojciec Totmesa III wspólnie z kap³anami Amona sprowokowa³ wybranie swego syna na króla. Mia³ to byæ cud. Podczas procesji barka Amona zboczy³a z drogi i zatrzyma³a siê przed dwuletnim wówczas ch³opcem. Hatszepsut objê³a w³adzê jako regentka z ma³oletnim Totmesem, jednak dwa lub trzy lata póŸniej (wed³ug innych Ÿróde³ siedem) og³osi³a siê faraonem. Ju¿ w kilka tygodni po objêciu w³adzy m³ody faraon zorganizowa³ pierwsz¹ w swej karierze wyprawê wojenn¹ do Azji Mniejszej. Celem tej wyprawy by³o pokonanie koalicji ksi¹¿¹t syryjskich. Totmes na czele 20 tysiêcy ¿o³nierzy pokonywa³ 20 km w ci¹gu dnia. Wojska buntownicze skoncentrowa³y swe si³y na pó³noc od góry Karmel. Totmes, aby zaskoczyæ wrogów, zdecydowa³ siê na trudniejsz¹ drogê przez prze³êcz Arun. Do decyduj¹cego starcia dosz³o pod Megiddo w 1469 roku p.n.e. Po kilkumiesiêcznym oblê¿eniu w rêce egipskie wpadli prawie wszyscy przywódcy koalicji z wyj¹tkiem ratuj¹cego siê ucieczk¹ w³adcy Kadeszu. Pokonani w³adcy z³o¿yli przysiêgê na wiernoœæ faraonowi. Wiêkszoœæ wydarzeñ z tej, a tak¿e szesnastu innych kampanii opisano w œwi¹tyni Amona w Karnaku w tzw. Rocznikach Totmesa. Wp³ywy Egiptu w tym czasie siêgnê³y po liniê Byblos-Damaszek, a w kolejnych latach panowania umacnia³y siê. W kilka lat póŸniej Totmes zdoby³ Kadesz. Do Egiptu zosta³y przy³¹czone wszystkie porty wybrze¿a fenickiego (jako przyczó³ki do l¹dowania wojsk oraz transportu ³upów). Podczas wyprawy do Kadesz Totmes popad³ w konflikt z pañstwem Mitanni. Zwyciêska dla Egipcjan bitwa pod Halab otworzy³a przed Totmesem drogê do Mezopotamii. Totmes wykorzysta³ sw¹ szansê i ruszy³ do góry Mitanni a potem na po³udnie. W tym czasie faraon polowa³ na s³onie. Na jednej z takich wypraw omal nie straci³ ¿ycia. Egipcjanie spustoszyli Syriê na zachód od Eufratu. Ko³o miasta Karkemisz Totmes postawi³ stelê ze swoim imieniem zaznaczaj¹c tym granicê swego pañstwa. PóŸniej Totmes poprowadzi³ kilka wypraw pacyfikacyjnych do Azji. Jedna z nich poœwiêcona by³a sprawdzeniu plonów w podbitych krainach i sprowadzeniu do Egiptu roœlin naturalnie w nim nie wystêpuj¹cych. Ogó³em Totmes III poprowadzi³ a¿ szesnaœcie kampanii wojennych do Syrii. Totmes III prowadzi³ swoje podboje nie tylko na Bliskim Wschodzie, ale równie¿ na po³udniu kraju. Potêdze armii egipskiej nie opar³a siê Nubia. Wojska faraona dotar³y a¿ do IV katarakty na Nilu. Granicê pañstwa ustanowiono w dzisiejszym Had¿ar-el-Merwa. Na prawym brzegu Totmes kaza³ wybudowaæ potê¿n¹ twierdzê Napata, skolonizowa³ wszystkie osady wzd³u¿ rzeki. Totmes z przywódcami podbitych pañstw utrzymywa³ przyjazne stosunki, co przyczynia³o siê do utworzenia swoistych stosunków dyplomatycznych. Do œmierci otrzymywa³ daniny z podbitych pañstw, a inne wrêcz przeœciga³y siê w wysy³aniu danin do Teb. Nawet silna w tym okresie Asyria czuj¹c zagro¿enie ze strony pañstwa Mitanni wys³a³a dary oddaj¹c siê pod opiekê faraona. Dziêki swym umiejêtnoœciom przywódczym i dyplomatycznym, a tak¿e cechom charakteru i wygl¹du zewnêtrznego, Totmes u potomnych zyska³ miano "Napoleona Egiptu" (nigdy nie przegra³ ¿adnej bitwy). Ostatecznie pañstwo faraonów za Totmesa III obejmowa³o czêœæ Azji Mniejszej, Sudan, Libiê, Palestynê, Syriê oraz tereny nad Eufratem. Totmes poszerzaj¹c granice Egiptu stworzy³ jego imperialn¹ potêgê w ówczesnym œwiecie. Uda³o siê skutecznie zaprowadziæ w pañstwie ³ad i porz¹dek, co umo¿liwi³o rozwój rzemios³a, budownictwa i sztuk piêknych. Totmes przebudowa³ œwi¹tyniê w Karnaku, na której œcianach wykuto tzw. Dzienniki Totmesa, opisuj¹ce 17 wypraw wojennych Totmesa. Szczególnie piêknym œwiadectwem wypraw do Asyrii jest tzw. Ogród botaniczny w œwi¹tyni w Karnaku z reliefami ukazuj¹cymi florê i faunê Palestyny i Asyrii. Wysoki poziom ¿ycia w Egipcie zapewni³ nap³yw bogactw z ca³ego imperium. Stolic¹ Egiptu w tym czasie by³y Teby, które za panowania Totmesa prze¿ywa³y swój najlepszy okres. ¯ycie w mieœcie skupia³o siê wokó³ œwi¹tyni Amona-Re (lokalnego bóstwa oraz jednoczeœnie ogólnopañstwowego boga-S³oñce). W czasie d³ugich nieobecnoœci króla w stolicy, wzros³a pozycja tebañskich kap³anów Amona. Totmes III zmar³ oko³o 1425 roku przed Chrystusem. Chc¹c unikn¹æ walki o w³adzê w pañstwie, na rok przed œmierci¹, ustanowi³ swego syna Amenhotepa II, wspó³panuj¹cym. Pierwotnie zosta³ pochowany w Dolinie Królów. Wejœcie do grobowca znajduje siê na skalnej pó³ce na wysokoœci kilkunastu metrów. Komora grobowa znajduje siê za d³ugim korytarzem i kilkoma mniejszymi salami. Wnêtrze grobu daje wra¿enie rozwiniêtego zwoju papirusu. Mumia zosta³a ograbiona ju¿ w czasach staro¿ytnych. Rozsypuj¹c¹ siê ze staroœci mumiê Faraona znaleziono w skrytce DB-320 w Deir el-Bahari. Zabalsamowane cia³o spoczywa³o w wewnêtrznej trumnie. Cia³o zosta³o zniszczone, g³owa od³amana od karku, a nogi od tu³owia, do skóry przyklei³y siê przesi¹kniête ¿ywic¹ banda¿e. Jedynie twarz zachowa³a siê nienaruszona.

TEXT.English: The bagh naka (Tiger Claw?) is a claw-like weapon from India designed to fit over the knuckles or be concealed under and against the palm. It consists of four or five curved blades affixed to a crossbar or glove, and is designed to slash through skin and muscle. It is believed to have been inspired by the armature of big cats, and the term bagh naka itself means tiger's claw in Hindi. Poisoned bagh naka had been used by the Rajput clans for assassinations. The most well-known usage of the weapon was by the first Maratha emperor Shivaji who used a bichuwa bagh naka to defeat the Bijapur general Afzal Khan. It was a popular weapon among the Nihang who wore it in their turbans and often held one in their left hand while wielding a larger weapon such as a sword in the right hand. It was recommended that Nihang women carry a bagh naka when going alone to dangerous areas.

The Tigurini were a clan or tribe forming one out of four pagi (provinces) of the Helvetiii. The Tigurini were the most important group of the Helvetiii, mentioned by both Caesar and Poseidonius, settling in the area of what is now the Swiss canton of Vaud, corresponding to the bearers of the late La Tène culture in western Switzerland. Their name has a meaning of "lords, rulers" (cognate with Irish tigern "lord"). The other Helvetiian tribes included the Verbigeni and the Tougeni (sometimes identified with the Teutones), besides one tribe that has remained unnamed.

Timur was a Turco-Mongol conqueror and the founder of the Timurid Empire in Persia and Central Asia. He was also the first ruler in the Timurid dynasty. Born into the Barlas confederation in Transoxiana during the 1320s or 1330s, Timur gained control of the western Chagatai Khanate by 1370. From that base, he led military campaigns across Western, South and Central Asia, Caucasus and southern Russia, and emerged as the most powerful ruler in the Muslim world after defeating the Mamluks of Egypt and Syria, the emerging Ottoman Empire and the declining Delhi Sultanate. From these conquests he founded the Timurid Empire, but this empire fragmented shortly after his death.

Joaquim Jos da Silva Xavier, known as Tiradentes (August 16, 1746-April 21, 1792), was a leading member of the Brazilian revolutionary movement known as the Inconfidencia Mineira whose aim was full independence from the Portuguese colonial power and to create a Brazilian republic. When the plan was discovered, Tiradentes was arrested, tried and publicly hanged. Since the 19th century he has been considered a national hero of Brazil.
TEXT.French: Joaquim José da Silva Xavier, connu sous le nom de Tiradentes (16 août 1746 - 21 avril 1792), fut un membre éminent du mouvement révolutionnaire brésilien appelé l'Inconfidência Mineira, dont l'objectif était l'indépendance totale du pouvoir colonial portugais et la création d'une république brésilienne. Lorsque le plan fut découvert, Tiradentes fut arrêté, jugé et pendu publiquement. Depuis le XIXe siècle, il est considéré comme un héros national du Brésil.
TEXT.Polish: Joaquim Jos da Silva Xavier, znany jako Tiradentes (August 16, 1746-April 21, 1792), by³ brazylijskim bojownikiem, który walczy³ przeciwko portugalskiej w³adzy kolonialnej w Minas Gerais. Zosta³ stracony, a jego cia³o podzielono na czêœci i rozwieziono po ulicach miast i wiosek ku przestrodze. Obecnie jest bohaterem narodowym Brazylii. 21 kwietnia obchodzi siê jego œwiêto.

TEXT.English: Tish-atal was endan of Urkesh during the Third Dynasty of Ur. He was one of the earliest known Hurrian rulers, but the archaeological record is fragmentary for this period, and no precise date can be ascribed to his reign.
TEXT.French: Tish-atal fut l'endan d'Urkesh durant la Troisième Dynastie d'Ur. Il fut l'un des plus anciens souverains hourrites connus, mais les registres archéologiques pour cette période sont fragmentaires et aucune date précise ne peut être attribuée à son règne.

TEXT.English: The Tlatilco War Priest is a unique unit of the Tlatilco culture, equivalent to the Obsidian Swordsman. It starts with the Fanatic and Herbal Cures promotions, and the standard swordsman's bonus for city attack.
TEXT.French: Le prêtre guerrier Tlatilco est une unité unique de la culture Tlatilco, équivalente à l'épéiste d'obsidienne. Il commence avec les promotions Fanatique et Remèdes à base de plantes, ainsi que le bonus standard pour l'attaque de ville de l'épéiste.
TEXT.Italian: Il sacerdote guerriero tlatilco sostituisce il guerriero con spada d'ossidiana. Inizia con le promozioni Fanatico ed Erbe mediche, oltre a mantenere i bonus standard degli spadaccini quando attacca una città.

TEXT.English: Tlatoani is the Nahuatl term for the ruler of an altepetl, a pre-Hispanic state. The word literally means "speaker", but may be translated into English as "king". A cihuatlahtoani is a female ruler, or queen regnant. The term cuauhtlatoani refers to "provisional, interim, or at least non-dynastic rulers". The leaders of the Mexica prior to their settlement are sometimes referred to as quauhtlatoque, as are those colonial rulers who were not descended from the ruling dynasty. The ruler's lands were called tlahtohcatlalli and the ruler's house was called tlahtohcacalli

The Tlaxcaltec Warrior is a unique unit of the Tlaxcaltec culture, equivalent to the Light Swordsman (even though he wields a sword of obsidian). It starts with the Shock I and Drill I promotion, and the standard swordsman's bonus for city attack. Thus it will be especially effective for storming a Classical city defended mostly by Melee units.
TEXT.French: Le guerrier tlaxcalte est une unité unique de la culture tlaxcalte, équivalente à l'épéiste léger (même s'il manie une épée en obsidienne). Il commence avec les promotions Choc I et Perfectionnement I, et le bonus standard pour l'attaque de ville de l'épéiste, ce qui le rend particulièrement efficace pour assiéger une ville classique défendue majoritairement par des unités de mêlée.
TEXT.Italian: Il guerriero tlaxcalteco equivale allo spadaccino leggero, anche se utilizza una spada di ossidiana. Inizia con le promozioni Shock I e Addestramento I, oltre ad avere i normali bonus attaccando le città. Perciò è l'ideale per attaccare una città difesa principalmente da unità da combattimento ravvicinato.

TEXT.English: Shah Abbas realized that in order to retain absolute control over his empire without antagonizing the Qizilbash, he needed to create reforms that reduced the dependency that the shah had on their military support. Part of these reforms was the creation of the 3rd force within the aristocracy and all other functions within the empire, but even more important in undermining the authority of the Qizilbash was the introduction of the Royal Corps into the military Musketers: realizing the advantages that the Ottomans had because of their firearms, Shah Abbas was at pains to equip both the qurchi and the ghulam soldiers with up-to-date weaponry. More importantly, for the first time in Iranian history, a substantial infantry corps of musketeers (tofang-chis), numbering 12 000, was created.

The Native American Indian used the Tomahawk for survival, protection and even smoking tobacco. Axe and knife throwing were social activities in Europe during the Renaissance and for the Vikings. Men of the early colonies involved in a skirmish were willing to throw away their muzzle shooters to continue the fight with the tomahawk.
TEXT.French: Les Amérindiens utilisaient le tomahawk pour la survie, la protection et même pour fumer le tabac. Le lancer de hache et de couteau étaient des activités sociales en Europe pendant la Renaissance et chez les Vikings. Les hommes des premières colonies engagés dans une escarmouche étaient prêts à abandonner leurs fusils à bouche pour continuer le combat avec le tomahawk.
TEXT.Polish: Rdzenni mieszkañcy ameryki u¿ywali tomahawków do walki, ochrony, a nawet do palenia tytoniu. Miotanie toporem czy no¿em by³o stosowane przez Wikingów oraz jako rodzaj aktywnoœci w epoce renesansu.

TEXT.English: Tomas Garrigue Masaryk was a Czechoslovak politician, sociologist and philosopher, who as an eager advocate of Czechoslovak independence during World War I became the founder and first President of Czechoslovakia, therefore is he called "President liberator". He originally wished to reform the Austro-Hungarian monarchy into a democratic federal state, but during the First World War he began to favour the abolition of the monarchy and, with the help of the Allied Powers, eventually succeeded.

Tomislav was a ruler of Croatia in the Middle Ages. He reigned from around 910 until 928, first as a duke (Latin: dux Croatorum) of the Duchy of Croatia, and then became the first king (rex Croatorum) of the Croatian Kingdom by the year 925. At the time of his rule Croatia forged an alliance with the Byzantines during their struggle with the Bulgarian Empire, with whom Croatia eventually went to war that culminated in the decisive Battle of the Bosnian Highlands in 926. To the north there were often conflicts with the Principality of Hungary, Croatia managed to keep its borders and to some extent expand on the disintegrated Duchy of Pannonia.

Tomols are plank-built boats, historically and currently used by the Chumash and Tongva Native Americans in the Santa Barbara and Los Angeles area. They were also called tii'at by the Tongva. Tomols are 8-30 feet (2.4-9.1 m) long. They were especially important as both tribes relied on the sea for sustenance. Tomols were preferably built out of redwood that had drifted down the coast. When supplies of redwood were lacking, local native pine was used. When splitting the wood the crafters would seek straight planks without knotholes, then sand them with sharkskin. To bind the wood together, small holes were drilled in the planks so they could be lashed to one another. Finally, the seams were caulked with 'yop', a mixture of hard tar and pine pitch melted and then boiled. Red paint and shell mosaics were often added as decorations.

Tore is a god of the forests who supplies animals to hunters. He is also a thunder god who appears as a storm and hides in rainbows. Most importantly, Tore appears as a leopard in the initiation rites. The first Pygmies stole fire from Tore; he chased them but could not catch them, and when he returned home, his mother had died. As punishment, he decreed that humans would also die, and he thus became the death god.
TEXT.French: Tore est un dieu des forêts qui fournit des animaux aux chasseurs. Il est aussi un dieu du tonnerre apparaissant comme une tempête et se cachant dans les arcs-en-ciel. Plus important encore, Tore paraît sous la forme d'un léopard lors des rites d'initiation. Les premiers Pygmées volèrent le feu à Tore ; il les poursuivit sans pouvoir les attraper, et à son retour chez lui, sa mère était morte. En punition, il décréta que les humains mourraient aussi, devenant ainsi le dieu de la mort.
TEXT.Polish: Tore jest bogiem polowañ w panteonie Pigmejów.

TEXT.English: A torpedo boat is a relatively small and fast naval ship designed to carry torpedoes into battle. The first designs rammed enemy ships with explosive spar torpedoes, and later designs launched self-propelled Whitehead torpedoes. They were created to counter battleships and other large, slow and heavily armed ships by speed and agility. A number of inexpensive boats attacking en masse could overwhelm a larger ship's ability to fight them off using its large, slow-firing guns. This way an inexpensive fleet of torpedo boats could defend against much larger and more expensive fleets, albeit only in the coastal areas to which their small size and limited fuel load restricted them.
TEXT.Polish: Torpedowiec - klasa niewielkich lub œredniej wielkoœci okrêtów, przeznaczonych g³ównie do wykonywania ataków torpedowych na okrêty nieprzyjaciela. Powsta³a pod koniec XIX wieku, kiedy to przypad³ te¿ szczyt popularnoœci torpedowców. Zast¹pione nastêpnie przez inne klasy okrêtów, by³y budowane i u¿ywane w mniejszych iloœciach do okresu II wojny œwiatowej.

TEXT.English: Toucans are members of the family Ramphastidae of near passerine birds from the Neotropics. The Ramphastidae family is most closely related to the American barbets. They are brightly marked and have large, often colorful bills. The family includes five genera and about forty different species. The name of this bird group is derived from the Tupi word tukana, via Portuguese. Toucans range in size from the Lettered Aracari (Pteroglossus inscriptus), at 130 g (4.6 oz) and 29 cm (11.5 inches), to the Toco Toucan (Ramphastos toco), at 680 g (1.5 lb) and 63 cm (29 inches). Their bodies are short (of comparable size to a crow's) and compact. The tail is rounded and varies in length, from half the length to the whole length of the body. The neck is short and thick. The wings are small, as they are forest-dwelling birds who only need to travel short distances, and are often of about the same span as the bill-tip-to-tail-tip measurements of the bird. The legs of a toucan are strong and rather short. Their toes are arranged in pairs with the first and fourth toes turned backward. The majority of toucans do not show any sexual dimorphism in their coloration, the genus Selenidera being the most notable exception to this rule (hence their common name, "dichromatic toucanets"). However, the bills of female toucans are usually shorter, deeper and sometimes straighter, giving more of a "blocky" impression compared to male bills. The feathers in the genus containing the largest toucans are generally black, with touches of white, yellow, and scarlet. The underparts of the araçaris (smaller toucans) are yellow, crossed by one or more black or red bands. The toucanets have mostly green plumage with blue markings. The colorful and large bill, which in some large species measures more than half the length of the body, is the hallmark of toucans. Despite its size, the toucan's bill is very light, being composed of bone struts filled with spongy tissue of keratin between them. The bill has forward-facing serrations resembling teeth, which historically led naturalists to believe that toucans captured fish and were primarily carnivorous; today it is known that they eat mostly fruit. Researchers have discovered that the large bill of the toucan is a highly efficient thermoregulation system, though its size may still be advantageous in other ways. It does aid in their feeding behavior (as they sit in one spot and reach for all fruit in range, thereby reducing energy expenditure), and it has also been theorized that the bill may intimidate smaller birds, so that the toucan may plunder nests undisturbed (see Diet below). Also, the beak allows the bird to reach deep into tree-holes to access food unavailable to other birds, and also to ransack suspended nests built by smaller birds. However, as there is no sexual dimorphism in coloration it is unlikely to be a sexual signal. A toucan's tongue is long (up to 14 - 15 cm, or 6 inches), narrow, grey, and singularly frayed on each side, adding to its sensitivity as an organ of taste. A structural complex probably unique to toucans involves the modification of several tail vertebrae. The rear three vertebrae are fused and attached to the spine by a ball and socket joint. Because of this, toucans may snap their tail forwards until it touches the head. This is the posture in which they sleep, often appearing simply as a ball of feathers, with the tip of the tail sticking out over the head.Toucans are arboreal and typically lay 2 - 4 white eggs in their nests. They make their nests in tree hollows and holes excavated by other animals such as woodpeckers, the toucan bill has very limited use as an excavation tool. When the eggs hatch, the young emerge completely naked, without any down. Toucans are resident breeders and do not migrate. Toucans are usually found in pairs or small flocks. They sometimes fence with their bills and wrestle, which scientists hypothesize they do to establish dominance hierarchies. Toucans are native to Southern Mexico, Central and South America, and the Caribbean region. They generally live in tropical and sub-tropical regions. They make their nests in tree hollows and holes excavated by other animals such as woodpeckers the toucan bill has very limited use as an excavation tool.
TEXT.French: Toucan est le nom vernaculaire de 12 espèces (soit en tout, 23 taxons) d'oiseaux de l'ordre des Piciformes et de la famille des Ramphastidés, proches des araçaris et des toucanets qui, dans le langage courant, sont aussi appelés « toucans ».[PARAGRAPH:2]Son long bec très léger et vascularisé lui permet de réguler sa température. Le toucan régule sa température grâce à son bec. Glenn Tattersall, de la Brock University (Canada), a trouvé un rôle à cet appendice qui représente près de la moitié de la surface corporelle de ces oiseaux. En les filmant en infrarouge, dès que la température dépasse 16°C, le bec du toucan s'échauffe jusqu'à une dizaine de degrés supplémentaire. Dans cet organe richement vascularisé, c'est le sang qui joue le rôle de liquide de refroidissement. Les vaisseaux, contractés pour éviter la déperdition de chaleur lorsqu'il fait froid, sont dilatés et irradient de la chaleur vers l'extérieur quand la température ambiante augmente. Comme dans les oreilles de l'éléphant, à la différence que la climatisation du toucan est quatre fois plus efficace que celle du pachyderme.
TEXT.German: Als [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Tukan[COLOR_REVERT] bezeichnet man eine Vogelfamilie, die zu den Spechtvögeln gehört. Es gibt sechs Gattungen und 45 Arten von Tukanen, wobei die kleineren Arten meist als Arassari bezeichnet werden.[NEWLINE]Tukane erreichen eine Körperlänge von 35-65 cm und besitzen relativ kurze Flügel und lange Schwänze. Auffälligstes Merkmal ist allerdings der riesige und prächtig gefärbte Schnabel. Er dient unter anderem zur Wärmeregulierung und wirkt bei hohen Temperaturen wie ein Kühlradiator. Die meisten Tukane haben zudem ein knallig buntes Gefieder (meist mit Gelbtönen), kombiniert mit glänzend schwarzen Gefiederpartien. Tukane leben in den tropischen Regionen Mittel- und Südamerikas. Sie sind reine Baumbewohner und ernähren sich vorwiegend von Früchten. Zuweilen steht auch Fleisch in Form von Insekten, Spinnentieren und sogar kleinen Reptilien oder Säugetieren auf dem Speiseplan. Tukane leben monogam und nisten in Baumhöhlen. Ein Gelege besteht aus zwei bis vier weißen Eiern, die zwei bis drei Wochen lang bebrütet werden.

TEXT.English: Watchmen were groups of men, usually authorised by a state, government, or society, to deter criminal activity and provide law enforcement. Watchmen have existed in various guises throughout the world and were generally succeeded by the emergence of formally organised policing.
TEXT.French: Les veilleurs étaient des groupes d'hommes, généralement autorisés par un État, un gouvernement ou une société, pour dissuader l'activité criminelle et assurer l'application de la loi. Les veilleurs ont existé sous diverses formes à travers le monde et ont généralement été remplacés par l'émergence de polices organisées formellement.
TEXT.Italian: Le sentinelle erano gruppi di uomini, generalmente autorizzati da uno stato, un governo o una società, per impedire l'attività criminale e fornire un supporto alla legge. Le sentinelle sono esistite in varie forme in tutto il mondo, e sono spesso state succedute da forze di polizia formalmente organizzate.
TEXT.Polish: Stra¿nicy miejscy to grupy ludzi, zwykle powo³ywanych przez pañstwo, rz¹d lub spo³ecznoœæ, do przeciwdzia³ania aktywnoœci przestêpczej oraz do egzekwowania prawa. Stra¿nicy miejscy istnieli w najró¿niejszych odmianach na ca³ym œwiecie i zostali zast¹pieni przez nowopowsta³e, formalnie zorganizowane si³y policyjne.

TEXT.English: Keying was a three-masted, 800-ton Foochow Chinese trading junk which sailed from China around the Cape of Good Hope to the United States and Britain between 1846 and 1848. Keying had been purchased in August 1846 in secrecy by British businessmen in Hong Kong, defying a Chinese law prohibiting the sale of Chinese ships to foreigners. She was renamed after the Manchu official Keying, based on an irregular romanization of his native name. The Keying was manned by 12 British and 30 Chinese sailors (the latter all Cantonese). She was commanded by Captain Charles Alfred Kellett, also British.

The troop transport ship, which in peacetime serves as a cargo or passenger vessel, is the principle means used by modern powers to move large quantities of military equipment and personnel over long distances. Because transports lack offensive weaponry, they require armed vessels as escorts during times of war. A properly escorted transport can move large military forces to a new area quickly to act as reinforcements or as an attacking force.
TEXT.French: Le bateau de transport de troupes qui, en temps de paix, transporte des marchandises ou des passagers, est le principal moyen utilisé par les grandes puissances contemporaines pour déplacer sur de longues distances de grandes quantités d'hommes et de matériel militaire. Ces bateaux n'ont pas d'armement offensif et, en temps de guerre, doivent donc être escortés. Un transport correctement défendu peut déplacer rapidement une force militaire importante, qu'il s'agisse de renforts ou d'une armée offensive.
TEXT.German: Das Transportschiff, das in Friedenszeiten als Fracht- oder Passagierschiff dient, wird von modernen Streitkräften eingesetzt, um standardmäßig größere Mengen Kriegsgerät und Militärpersonal möglichst schnell zum jeweiligen Kriegsschauplatz zu befördern. Da sich keine Angriffswaffen an Bord befinden, müssen Transportschiffe in Kriegszeiten durch bewaffneten Geleitschutz gesichert werden. Ein vernünftig beschütztes Transportschiff kann rasch große Truppenmengen als Verstärkung oder zum Angriff in ein neues Gebiet bringen.
TEXT.Italian: Le navi per il trasporto di truppe, che in tempo di pace sono utilizzate come cargo o navi passeggeri, vengono impiegate dagli eserciti per trasferire grandi quantità di equipaggiamento militare e di uomini sulle lunghe distanze. A causa della loro fragilità difensiva, i trasporti devono essere scortati, in tempo di guerra, da navi militari. Con queste navi, se ben scortate, si possono muovere rapidamente imponenti forze d'attacco o di difesa da una zona all'altra.
TEXT.Spanish: El transporte de tropas, que en tiempos de paz sirve como nave de transporte comercial o de pasajeros, es el principal medio usado por las potencias modernas para trasladar grandes cantidades de equipo o personal militar a grandes distancias. Debido a que los transportes no poseen armamento ofensivo, en tiempos de guerra hay que escoltarlos con naves armadas. Un transporte adecuadamente protegido puede trasladar rápidamente gran cantidad de tropas hasta un territorio recién conquistado, bien como refuerzos o bien como fuerza de ataque.

TEXT.English: Ophir is a port or region mentioned in the Bible, famous for its wealth. King Solomon received a cargo of gold, silver, sandalwood, pearls, ivory, apes and peacocks from Ophir, every three years.
TEXT.French: Ophir est un port ou une région mentionné dans la Bible, célèbre pour sa richesse. Le roi Salomon recevait un chargement d'or, d'argent, de bois de santal, de perles, d'ivoire, de singes et de paons provenant d'Ophir, tous les trois ans.

TEXT.English: Treasure (from - thesauros, meaning "treasure store", romanized as thesaurus) is a concentration of riches, often one which is considered lost or forgotten until being rediscovered. Some jurisdictions legally define what constitutes treasure, such as in the British Treasure Act 1996. The phrase "blood and treasure" or "lives and treasure" has been used to refer to the human and monetary costs associated with massive endeavours such as war that expend both.

A Chinese treasure ship was a type of large wooden ship in the fleet of admiral Zheng He, who led seven voyages during the early 15th-century Ming Dynasty. Scholars disagree about the factual accuracy and correct interpretation of accounts of the treasure ships. The purported dimensions of these ships at 137 m (450 ft) long and 55 m (180 ft wide) are at least twice as long as the largest European ships at the end of the sixteenth century. The British scientist, historian and sinologist Joseph Needham stated in his monumental research work Science and Civilisation in China that the ships were between 400 feet to 600 feet in length - greater than the Greek tessarakonteres of 3rd century BC, which were reported to be as long as 128 m (425 ft). Treasure ships' dimensions are debated on practical engineering grounds, with some suggesting they were as short as 61-76 m (200-250 feet) or that they could only have been used on special occasions in the relative safety of the lower Yangtze River. Although a claimed treasure ship rudder has been unearthed in Nanjing, its size is no larger than rudders known to have been used in sub 60 metre Jiangsu trading ships of the 1930s.

The trebuchet was a medieval siege weapon designed to throw a projectile a great distance through the air. The trebuchet originated in China sometime between the fifth and third centuries BC. From there it spread to the west, reaching Europe around 500 AD. [PARAGRAPH:2:1]Although it is usually thought of as a type of catapult, the trebuchet is in fact a gigantic sling attached to a lever. The shorter arm of the lever carries a counterweight, while the longer arm carries the sling that throws the projectile. In operation the sling end is pulled towards the ground (lifting the counterweight in the process) and held in place by a trigger while a projectile is loaded into the sling. When the trigger is released, the counterweight falls and the sling flies up and above the machine, releasing the projectile at the top of its arc. [PARAGRAPH:2:1]Constructed properly, trebuchets could fire very heavy loads. In modern reconstructions using trebuchets built with the original tools and materials, trebuchets have been able to throw projectiles weighing as much as 300 kilograms. Aiming the trebuchet was difficult and required some practice and knowledge of engineering - both of which were usually in short supply for medieval operators. Trebuchets were also extremely heavy and almost immobile; this, combined with their slow rate of their fire, made them impractical for anything except siege operations. [PARAGRAPH:2:1]Although the Chinese were the first to develop the trebuchet, by the time of the Mongol invasions the Chinese had fallen behind other parts of the world in siege technology. This was due to the fact that China had been politically united for long periods of time, preventing the formation of strong fortresses across the country, and the traditional enemies of the Chinese were nomadic warriors - not fortified city-dwellers. Nevertheless, the Chinese were still far more advanced in siege warfare than the Mongols, and it was not until the Mongols adopted Chinese practices that they began to have success capturing enemy fortifications. [PARAGRAPH:2:1]Late in the conquest of Song China, Mongol leader Kublai Khan brought in Arab engineers from the Mongol holdings in Persia to build hinged counterweight trebuchets, which were more advanced than anything yet seen in China. With the aid of these powerful weapons, Kublai was able to take the previously-impenetrable fortress of Xiangyang in 1273, and from there rapidly take the rest of Song China's cities, completing his conquest of the Song Empire in 1279. [PARAGRAPH:2:1]
TEXT.French: Le trébuchet est une arme de siège médiévale, servant à lancer un projectile à une longue distance. Il est créé en Chine entre le Ve et le IIIe siècle av. J.-C., et se répand ensuite vers l'ouest, atteignant l'Europe vers 500 ap. J.-C. [PARAGRAPH:2:1]Bien qu'il soit généralement considéré comme une sorte de catapulte, le trébuchet est en fait une gigantesque fronde attachée à un levier. Le bras le plus court du levier comporte un contrepoids tandis que le bras le plus long contient la fronde qui lance le projectile. Lors de son utilisation, l'extrémité de la fronde est tendue vers le sol, ce qui soulève le contrepoids, et maintenue par une cheville pendant que le projectile est installé dans la fronde. Lorsque la cheville est relâchée, le contrepoids tombe, la fronde s'élève au-dessus de l'appareil et éjecte le projectile lorsqu'elle se trouve à son apogée. [PARAGRAPH:2:1]Construits correctement, les trébuchets peuvent projeter de très lourdes charges. Dans des reconstitutions modernes utilisant des trébuchets fabriqués avec les outils et matériaux d'origine, les trébuchets sont capables de lancer des projectiles pesant 300 kg. Il est difficile de manoeuvrer le trébuchet, cela requiert pratique et connaissance de l'ingénierie qui étaient toutes deux peu courantes pour les opérateurs médiévaux. Les trébuchets sont aussi extrêmement lourds et presque immobiles. Combinés à leur lente fréquence de tir, tous ces inconvénients le rendent inutilisable excepté pour les opérations de siège. [PARAGRAPH:2:1]Si les Chinois sont les premiers à avoir développé le trébuchet, à l'époque des invasions mongoles, ils sont vite dépassés par d'autres régions du monde en matière de technologie de siège. Cela s'explique par le fait que les Chinois ont été politiquement unifiés pendant très longtemps et n'ont donc pas eu besoin de construire de solides forteresses dans le pays. Par ailleurs, les ennemis traditionnels des Chinois sont des guerriers nomades qui ne vivent pas dans des cités fortifiées. Toutefois, les Chinois sont bien plus avancés que les Mongols pour la guerre de siège et ce n'est que lorsque ces derniers adoptent les pratiques chinoises qu'ils commencent à réussir à attaquer les fortifications ennemies. [PARAGRAPH:2:1]Tardivement, lors de la conquête de la Chine des Song, le leader mongol Kubilai Khan fait appel à des ingénieurs arabes, originaires de territoires perses détenus par les Mongols, pour construire des trébuchets à contrepoids articulé, qui sont bien plus avancés que tout ce qui existe alors en Chine. A l'aide de ces puissantes armes, Kubilai parvient à s'emparer de la forteresse autrefois imprenable de Xiangyang en 1273 et, de là, à s'approprier rapidement les autres villes de la Chine des Song, achevant sa conquête de l'Empire Song en 1279. [PARAGRAPH:2:1]
TEXT.German: Der Tribok war eine mittelalterliche Belagerungswaffe, mit der Geschosse über große Entfernungen hinweg durch die Luft geschleudert wurden. Er wurde ursprünglich irgendwann zwischen dem 5. und 3. Jahrhundert vor Christus in China entwickelt. Von dort aus gelangte er immer weiter nach Westen und wurde um 500 nach Christus erstmals auch in Europa eingesetzt. [PARAGRAPH:2:1]Obwohl er in der Regel wie eine Art Katapult beschrieben wird, handelt es sich bei dem Tribok tatsächlich um eine gigantische Schleuder mit einem Hebelmechanismus. An dem kürzeren Hebel ist ein Gegengewicht befestigt, während der längere Hebel die Schlinge steuert, die das Geschoss abfeuert. Im Betrieb wird das Schlingenende zu Boden gezogen (wobei das Gegengewicht angehoben wird) und mit einem Abzugshebel fixiert, während das Geschoss in die Schlinge geladen wird. Wird der Abzugshebel gelöst, fällt das Gegengewicht herunter, die Schlinge fliegt nach oben - über die Maschine hinweg - und das Geschoss wird dabei am höchsten Punkt der Schwungbogenbewegung herausgeschleudert. [PARAGRAPH:2:1]Wenn sie richtig konstruiert waren, konnten die Triboken mit sehr schweren Geschossen beladen werden. Moderne Nachbauten, für die originale Werkzeuge und Materialien verwendet wurden, haben gezeigt, dass Triboken Geschosse von bis zu 300 Kilogramm Gewicht aufnehmen können. Das Zielen war mit einem Tribok allerdings recht schwierig und erforderte einige Übung sowie technische Kenntnisse - und beides war bei den mittelalterlichern Bedienern dieser Waffen eher selten vorhanden. Außerdem waren Triboken extrem schwer und nahezu unbeweglich. Bedenkt man dann noch ihre geringe Schussfrequenz, waren sie wirklich ausschließlich für Belagerungsangriffe geeignet. [PARAGRAPH:2:1]Obwohl die Chinesen den Tribok als Erste entwickelt hatten, hinkten sie zur Zeit des Einmarschs der Mongolen den Belagerungstechnologien anderer Länder der Welt bereits weit hinterher. Der Grund hierfür war, dass China über lange Perioden hinweg politisch geeint war, wodurch die Errichtung starker Festungen im Land unnötig gewesen war. Zudem waren die traditionellen Feinde der Chinesen stets Nomadenkrieger gewesen und keine Bewohner befestigter Städte. Trotzdem waren die Chinesen den Mongolen in punkto Belagerungskriegsführung immer noch überlegen und erst nachdem die Mongolen Chinas Technologien übernommen hatten, waren sie auch in der Lage, feindliche Festungen einzunehmen. [PARAGRAPH:2:1]Gegen Ende der Belagerung des von der Song-Dynastie regierten China setzte der mongolische Herrscher Kublai Khan arabische Baumeister aus den mongolischen Ländereien in Persien ein, um klappbare Gegengewicht-Triboken zu bauen, die erheblich fortschrittlicher waren als die Triboken der Chinesen. Mithilfe dieser Waffen war Kublai Khan in der Lage, im Jahr 1273 die zuvor uneinnehmbare Festung Xiang-yang zu erobern und von dort aus innerhalb kurzer Zeit auch die übrigen Städte der Song-Dynastie einzunehmen, so dass er seinen Eroberungsfeldzug des Song-Reiches im Jahr 1279 vollenden konnte. [PARAGRAPH:2:1]
TEXT.Italian: Il trabocco era un'arma d'assedio medievale progettata per scagliare in aria proiettili a grandi distanze. Il trabocco nacque in Cina tra il quinto e il terzo secolo a.C.. Da lì il suo uso si diffuse verso ovest, raggiungendo l'Europa intorno al 500 d.C. [PARAGRAPH:2:1]Anche se di solito lo si pensa come una specie di catapulta, il trabocco è in realtà un'enorme fionda agganciata a una leva. Il braccio più corto della leva porta un contrappeso, mentre quello più lungo è collegato alla fionda con il proiettile. Quando è attivato, la fionda viene tirata verso il terreno (il contrappeso, per contro, si solleva) e tenuta in posizione da un grilletto mentre il proiettile viene caricato nella fionda. Quando il grilletto viene rilasciato, il contrappeso cade e la fionda vola sopra il trabocco, scagliando il proiettile nel punto più alto del suo arco. [PARAGRAPH:2:1]Se costruito correttamente, il trabocco poteva scagliare oggetti molto pesanti. Nelle moderne ricostruzioni con i materiali e le tecniche dell'epoca, si sono potuti scagliare pesi anche di 300 chili. Prendere la mira col trabocco era difficile e occorreva pratica e qualche nozione di ingegneria, cose che spesso mancavano a chi li manovrava nel Medioevo. I trabocchi erano anche estremamente pesanti e praticamente immobili; questo e la bassa frequenza dei colpi li rendevano utili solo negli assedi. [PARAGRAPH:2:1]Anche se furono i Cinesi i primi a svilupparlo, al tempo delle invasioni dei Mongoli la tecnologia per assedi cinese era ormai arretrata rispetto al resto del mondo e questo per via dell'unione politica di lunga durata, che aveva reso inutile la costruzione di grandi fortezze in tutto il Paese, e per via della natura dei loro nemici, che erano tribù nomadi e non cittadini residenti in centri fortificati. Ciò nonostante la tecnologia d'assedio cinese era più avanzata di quella dei Mongoli e fu solo quando questi ultimi adottarono le tecniche cinesi che riuscirono a dar loro del filo da torcere. [PARAGRAPH:2:1]In seguito, al momento di conquistare la Cina dei Song, il capo mongolo Kublai Khan portò con sé degli ingegneri arabi (provenienti dai possedimenti mongoli in Persia) affinché costruissero trabocchi muniti di cardini e contrappesi, molto più avanzati di qualsiasi arma vista prima in Cina. Fu grazie all'aiuto di queste potenti armi che Kublai riuscì a prendere l'altrimenti impenetrabile fortezza di Xiangyang nel 1273 e da lì partire alla conquista del resto della Cina, completata nel 1279. [PARAGRAPH:2:1]
TEXT.Spanish: El trabuquete era una máquina de asedio medieval diseñada para arrojar un proyectil a gran distancia. Se inventó en China, en algún momento entre los siglos V y III a. C. Desde allí se extendió hacia el oeste y llegó a Europa alrededor del año 500 d. C. [PARAGRAPH:2:1]Aunque suele pensarse que es un tipo de catapulta, el trabuquete es en realidad una gigantesca honda unida a una palanca. El brazo corto de la palanca lleva un contrapeso, mientras que el brazo largo propulsa la honda que lanza el proyectil. Para armarse, el brazo de la honda se baja hasta el suelo (levantando el contrapeso en el proceso) y se sujeta mediante un sistema de disparador mientras se carga el proyectil. Cuando se acciona el disparador, el contrapeso cae, la honda se eleva por encima de la maquinaria y, al llegar al cenit de su ascenso, suelta el proyectil. [PARAGRAPH:2:1]Si están bien construidos, los trabuquetes pueden lanzar proyectiles muy pesados. En reconstrucciones modernas de trabuquetes realizadas con las herramientas y los materiales de la época, se han llegado a lanzar proyectiles de hasta trescientos kilos. Apuntar con el trabuquete era difícil y requería práctica y conocimientos de ingeniería, habilidades que no abundaban demasiado en los artilleros medievales. Además, eran extremadamente pesados y casi inmóviles. Esto, combinado con su lenta cadencia de fuego, hacía que fuesen muy poco prácticos, salvo como máquinas de asedio. [PARAGRAPH:2:1]Aunque los chinos habían inventado esta máquina, en tiempos de las invasiones mongolas su tecnología de asedios había quedado rezagada con respecto a la de otras partes del mundo. En parte, esto se debía al hecho de que China llevaba mucho tiempo unificada políticamente, lo que había impedido la aparición de importantes fortalezas en su territorio, ya que los enemigos tradicionales de los chinos eran guerreros nómadas, no pueblos con ciudades fortificadas. No obstante, los chinos seguían estando muy por encima de los mongoles en cuanto a maquinaria de asedio y, hasta que los nómadas no empezaron a adoptar sus técnicas de poliorcética, no tuvieron ningún éxito en la captura de fortificaciones. [PARAGRAPH:2:1]En las fases finales de la conquista de la China Song, el líder mongol Kublai kan trajo ingenieros árabes de las posesiones mongolas en Arabia para que le construyeran grandes trabuquetes, más avanzados que cualquiera que se hubiese visto en China hasta la fecha. Con la ayuda de estas poderosas armas, Kublai fue capaz de tomar la hasta entonces inexpugnable fortaleza de Xiangyang en 1273 y, a partir de allí, el resto de la China Song, cuya conquista se culminó en 1279. [PARAGRAPH:2:1]

TEXT.English: The Trench Cavalry is the last of the horse units in a military setting. They were used at the start of WWI, before the lines stagnated.
TEXT.French: La cavalerie de tranchées est la dernière des unités à cheval dans un contexte militaire. Elle fut utilisée au début de la Première Guerre mondiale, avant que les lignes ne stagnent.
TEXT.Italian: La cavalleria da trincea è stato l'ultimo tipo di cavalleria utilizzata in guerra; venne usata all'inizio della I guerra mondiale, prima che le linee si consolidassero.
TEXT.Polish: Wojna pozycyjna - wojna, podczas której obie walcz¹ce strony zajmuj¹ silnie umocnione pozycje (okopy, zasieki). Miêdzy walcz¹cymi stronami znajduje siê tzw. ziemia niczyja, nad któr¹ ¿adna ze stron nie ma kontroli. Wyparcie przeciwnika, a tym samym przesuniêcie linii frontu, jest bardzo utrudnione. Wojna taka charakteryzuje siê ma³¹ ruchliwoœci¹ frontu, d³ugotrwa³ymi walkami zaczepno-obronnymi oraz ma³ym tempem dzia³añ zmierzaj¹cych do prze³amania obrony nieprzyjaciela. Wojna pozycyjna by³a charakterystyczna podczas I wojny œwiatowej dla frontu zachodniego. W tej wojnie obie strony wierzy³y, i¿ przewaga liczebna pozwoli na odniesienie ostatecznego zwyciêstwa, mimo zwiêkszonej si³y obrony, wyposa¿onej w zmechanizowany sprzêt bojowy. Wojna ta przynosi³a ogromne straty w ludziach (np. w bitwie pod Verdun). W póŸniejszych czasach tak¿e dochodzi³o do wojny pozycyjnej, np. podczas walk o Madryt (1936-1939), oblê¿enia Leningradu (1941-1944), bitwy o Sewastopol (1941-1942), wojny koreañskiej (1950-1953) i wojny iracko-irañskiej (1980-1988).

TEXT.English: At the start of World War I, most armies prepared for a brief war whose strategy and tactics would have been familiar to Napoleon. Indeed, a number of horse cavalry units were brought to the front by train, commanded by officers who did not imagine the factors that would render them useless. Most of these units were never deployed. Infantry, armed with bolt action rifles and augmented by machine guns, needed only to dig to become nigh invulnerable. To attack frontally was to court crippling losses, so an outflanking operation was essential. After the Battle of the Aisne in September 1914, an extended series of attempted flanking moves, and matching extensions to the fortified defensive lines, soon saw the celebrated "race to the sea"; German and Allied armies produced essentially a matched pair of trench lines from the Swiss border in the south to the North Sea coast of Belgium. Trench warfare prevailed on the Western Front from September 16, 1914, until the Germans launched their "Spring Offensive", Operation Michael, on March 21, 1918.

Miêdzy walcz¹cymi stronami znajduje siê tzw. ziemia niczyja, nad któr¹ ¿adna ze stron nie ma kontroli. Wyparcie przeciwnika, a tym samym przesuniêcie linii frontu, jest bardzo utrudnione. TEXT.English: In the late 19th century, Gatling guns and other externally powered types such as the Nordenfelt were often made in a variety of calibers, such as 0.5-inch and 1-inch. Due to their multiple barrels, overheating was not so much of an issue, but they were also quite heavy. When Maxim developed his recoil-powered machine gun using a single barrel, his first main design weighed a modest 26 pounds (11.8 kg) and fired a 0.45-inch rifle-caliber bullet from a 24-inch barrel. A famous photo of Maxim showed him picking it up by its 15-pound tripod (6.8 kg) with one arm. It was similar to present-day medium machine guns, but it could not be fired for extended periods due to overheating. As a result, Maxim created a water jacket cooling system to enable it to fire for extended periods. However, this added significant weight, as did the change to more powerful rifle cartridges.
TEXT.Polish: Okopowy Karabin Maszynowy - rodzina karabinów maszynowych, której pierwowzorem by³ ciê¿ki karabin maszynowy Hirama Maxima skonstruowany w 1883 roku. By³a to broñ skomplikowana, droga w produkcji i wymagaj¹ca dobrze wyszkolonej obs³ugi, ale przewy¿szaj¹ca pod ka¿dym wzglêdem u¿ywane wczeœniej kartaczownice.

TEXT.English: The Tribal Guardian protects your capital against all intruders. It refuses to leave the palace of the ruler.
TEXT.French: Le Gardien Tribal protège votre capitale contre tous les intrus. Il refuse de quitter le palais du souverain.
TEXT.German: In einer Umwelt voll wilder Raubtiere und feindlicher Horden konnten die frühen Menschen ihre Lager unmöglich ohne Bewachung zurücklassen. Wenn die Männer der Sippe zur Jagd aufbrachen, mussten einige als Wächter zurückbleiben, um Frauen, Kinder, Alte und Schwache, aber auch Nahrungsvorräte und Ressourcen vor Übergriffen (auch aus den eigenen Reihen) zu schützen.
TEXT.Italian: Il guardiano tribale protegge la tua capitale dagli intrusi; si rifiuta di abbandonare il palazzo del capo.
TEXT.Polish: Gwardia (w³. guardia - stra¿) - pocz¹tkowo stra¿ przyboczna monarchy lub wodza, póŸniej doborowe oddzia³y liniowe. Stacjonowa³y g³ównie w stolicy pañstwa.

TEXT.Spanish: El Guardián tribal protege tu capital de los intrusos. Él rehúsa abandonar el palacio del líder.

TEXT.English: A tribe, viewed historically or developmentally, consists of a social group existing before the development of, or outside of, states. Many anthropologists use the term to refer to societies organized largely on the basis of kinship, especially corporate descent groups (see clan and kinship). Some theorists hold that tribes represent a stage in social evolution intermediate between bands and states. Other theorists argue that tribes developed after, and must be understood in terms of their relationship to, states. Some criticize its connotations as a way of attaching "backwardness" and the racist notion of primitive since the term "tribe" is largely used to describe non-White peoples.
TEXT.Polish: [BOLD]Plemiê[\BOLD], grupa spokrewnionych rodów wywodz¹cych siê od wspólnego przodka (w odró¿nieniu od szczepu), zamieszkuj¹cych jeden obszar i po³¹czonych wspólnymi zwi¹zkami spo³ecznymi i ekonomicznymi.[NEWLINE][PARAGRAPH:1]Plemiê ma œwiadomoœæ bliskiego pokrewieñstwa, pos³uguje siê tym samym dialektem i jest po³¹czone wyznawaniem tego samego kultu religijnego. Definicja "krewniacza" plemienia mo¿e byæ te¿, w niektórych przypadkach (np. plemiona s³owiañskie), zast¹piona definicj¹ terytorialn¹. Wed³ug tej definicji plemiê to lokalna wspólnota osadnicza z³o¿ona z kilku lub kilkunastu mniejszych wspólnot terytorialnych (np. w Polsce t¹ mniejsz¹ wspólnot¹ by³o opole).

TEXT.English: Triremes were ancient war galleys with three rows of oars on each side. The trireme was an improvement upon an older type of ship called the "pentekonter," which was similar in design but possessed only one row of oars on each side. (The standard "galleys" found in Civilization IV are pentekonters.) The staggered seating of the rowers on the trireme allowed for more people to be packed into roughly the same amount of space, and (more importantly) the extra manpower allowed triremes to travel at faster speeds. Some ancient sources claim that the trireme existed as far back as the eighth century BC, but the first known account of their use was by Polycrates of Samos in 525 BC during an invasion of Egypt. By the middle of the fifth century BC, triremes were in common use throughout Greece.[PARAGRAPH:1]The average trireme was about 35 meters long, carrying 170 oarsmen, 20 crew members, and 10 marines under the command of a captain. According to ancient sources, triremes could reach a maximum speed of about 20 km/hour in battle, or sustain a slower speed of 13 km/hour for a long stretch of time. Triremes also possessed sails but they were not used during combat. A Trireme's main offensive weapon was its "beak," a stout piece of sharpened wood (often clad in metal) which protruded directly forward from its bow, at or below the waterline. In battle the primary tactic was to use the beaks to ram and sink enemy ships, which required building up as much speed as possible to punch through the opposing ship's hull. This was a difficult task and required a great deal of cooperation from the rowers, as even a single rower moving out of place could greatly slow the ship. For this reason the rowers on Greek triremes were not slaves but instead well-trained free men who received good pay for their services.[PARAGRAPH:1]During the Persian War, the Greeks used their triremes to defeat the Persians at the decisive Battle of Salamis. Triremes also formed the backbone of the Athenian navy during the Peloponnesian War. As the war progressed Sparta and her allies created their own powerful fleet of triremes; these would be put into good use in 404 BC during the Battle at Aegospotami, when Lysander destroyed Athen's navy, cutting off the city-state's trade and eventually starving her into submission.[PARAGRAPH:1]Triremes would eventually be supplanted by the larger and faster quinqueremes, but the design was revived years later by the Romans, who, facing no major naval enemies, preferred the smaller and cheaper triremes to the more expensive quinqueremes.
TEXT.French: La trirème est une galère de guerre disposant de trois rangs de rames sur chaque bord. Elle constitue une amélioration d'un type plus ancien de bateau appelé le pentécontère à la conception similaire mais avec un seul rang de rameurs sur chaque bord (le pentécontère est la "galère" standard de Civilization IV). L'échelonnement des rameurs sur la trirème permet d'en entasser plus sur une même surface et surtout lui permet de bénéficier d'une puissance supérieure autorisant une vitesse plus rapide. D'après certaines sources anciennes, la trirème existait déjà au huitième siècle av. J.-C., mais la première mention de son utilisation est faite par Polycrate de Samos en 525 av. J.-C. lors d'une invasion de l'Egypte. Au début du cinquième siècle av. J.-C., les trirèmes existent partout en Grèce.[PARAGRAPH:1]Une trirème mesure en moyenne 35 mètres de long et transporte 170 rameurs, 20 hommes d'équipage et 10 marins placés sous le commandement d'un capitaine. Elle peut atteindre une vitesse maximale de 20 km/h au combat et maintenir une vitesse de croisière de 13 km/h pendant une longue période. La trirème dispose aussi de voiles, mais celles-ci ne sont pas utilisées au combat. L'armement principal est constitué par un rostre, pièce de bois très robuste montée sur sa proue au niveau ou au-dessous de la ligne de flottaison et généralement renforcée de métal. Au combat, la principale tactique est d'utiliser le rostre pour éperonner et couler un navire ennemi, ce qui implique de prendre le plus de vitesse possible avant d'aller percuter la coque de l'embarcation adverse. C'est une manoeuvre difficile nécessitant l'entière coopération des rameurs, car même le déplacement d'un seul rameur peut grandement ralentir la trirème. C'est la raison pour laquelle les rameurs des trirèmes grecques ne sont pas des esclaves mais des hommes libres bien entraînés qui recevaient une bonne solde pour leurs services.[PARAGRAPH:1]Au cours des guerres médiques, les Grecs utilisent leurs trirèmes pour vaincre l'ennemi perse lors de la bataille décisive de Salamine. Les trirèmes forment aussi l'épine dorsale de la flotte athénienne au cours de la Guerre du Péloponnèse. Sparte et ses alliés constituent progressivement leur propre puissante flotte de trirèmes pendant la guerre. Elles s'avèrent très utiles en 404 av. J.-C. à la bataille d'Aigos Potamos quand Lysandre réussit à détruire la flotte athénienne et coupe les routes d'approvisionnement d'Athènes, affamant la cité-état ennemie et la soumettant enfin.[PARAGRAPH:1]Les trirèmes finissent par être supplantées par les plus grandes et plus rapides quinquérèmes, mais le modèle réapparaît bien des années plus tard chez les Romains qui, ne faisant face à aucune menace navale sérieuse, préfèrent les plus petites trirèmes aux quinquérèmes, bien plus coûteuses.

TEXT.English: Trisong Detsen was one of the emperors of Tibet and ruled from 755 until 797 or 804 CE. Trisong Detsen was the second of the Three Dharma Kings of Tibet, playing a pivotal role in the introduction of Buddhism to Tibet and the establishment of the Nyingma, or 'Ancient' school of Tibetan Buddhism. He was said to have hosted a famous two-year debate from 792-794CE, known in Western scholarship as the "Council of Lhasa" (although it took place at Samye) outside the capital. He sponsored a Dharma debate between the Chinese Ch'an Meditation Master Mo-ho-yen (who represented the third documented wave of Ch'an dissemination in Tibet) and the scholar Kamalashila, a student of Shantarakshita. Effectively the debate was between the Chinese and Indian Buddhist traditions as they were represented in Tibet. In 763 Trisong Detsen responded to Chinese pressure from the north by sending an army of 200,000 men to the border, defeating the forces there and then continuing on to take Chang'an, the Chinese capital, forcing the Emperor to flee the capital. In 783 a peace treaty was negotiated between China and Tibet giving Tibet all lands in the Kokonor region. The King also formed an alliance with King Imobsun of Siam in 778, joining forces to attack the Chinese in Sichuan. Trisong Detsen next sought to expand westward, reaching the Oxus River and threatening the Arab Caliph, Harun al-Rashid. The Caliph was concerned enough to establish an alliance with the Chinese emperor, and perhaps this alone prevented Tibet from taking control of the Middle East and points beyond. Through the remainder of his reign the King would be preoccupied with Arab wars in the west, taking pressure off his Chinese opponents to the east and north, until his rule ended in 797. Trisong Detsen retired to live at Zungkar and handed power to his second son, Mun Tsenpo, in 797. From this point there is much confusion in the various historical sources. It seems there was a struggle for the succession after the death of Trisong Detsen. It is not clear when Trisong Detsen died, or for how long Mune Tsenpo reigned.
TEXT.Polish: Trisong Decen by³ królem Tybetu w latach 755 - 797 lub 804 n.e. W roku 756, po jednorocznym bezkrólewiu, ksi¹¿ê Song Decen osi¹gn¹³ wiek uprawniaj¹cy go do przejêcia samodzielnej w³adzy (13 lat wg tradycji tybetañskiej) i zosta³ ukoronowany pod imieniem Trisong Decen (756 - 797). W jego osobie na tronie Tybetu zasiad³ kolejny wielki król. Jest on wspominany przez teksty buddyjskie jako zdecydowany zwolennik i propagator nauki Buddy - mówi siê o nim jako o "królu nauki" (dharmarad¿a) i emanacji Manjushri, bodhisattwy m¹droœci. Na jego zaproszenie przyby³ do Tybetu indyjski uczony (pandit) Santaraksita, który mia³ za zadanie propagowaæ tu buddyzm. Z jego obecnoœci jednak nie byli zadowoleni liczni ministrowie, a ca³y szereg niefortunnych zdarzeñ towarzysz¹cych Santaraksicie by³ interpretowany jako przejaw z³oœci bóstw tybetañskich (tzn. bóstw religii bon). Z tego powodu uczony wkrótce wyjecha³ z Tybetu, ale przed odjazdem poradzi³ królowi, aby wezwa³ do Tybetu wielkiego hinduskiego guru i adepta tantry, Padmasambhavê (zwanego te¿ Guru Rinpocze). Padmasambhava pochodzi³ z legendarnej krainy Oddiyana, której po³o¿enie nie jest do koñca ustalone (lokalizuje siê j¹ w p³n. Pakistanie u podnó¿a Karakorum lub w indyjskim stanie Orisa). Tradycja utrzymuje, ¿e gdy guru przyby³ do Tybetu, pokona³ z³e demony (tzn. bóstwa religii bon), a potem móg³ zaj¹æ siê szerzeniem dharmy. Jego uczniem zosta³ te¿ król Trisong Decen. Gdy Padmasambhava odniós³ w Tybecie sukces, do³¹czy³ do niego Santaraksita. Do dziœ Padmasambhavie przypisuje siê za³o¿enie najstarszego tybetañskiego klasztoru Samje (na p³d. od Lhasy) i stworzenie ningma - jednej z czterech g³ównych tradycji buddyzmu tybetañskiego.

TEXT.English: For most of his life Leon Trotsky was a man without a country, banished from one land to another. He was born in Ukraine of Jewish parents named Bronstein. In 1900 he was exiled to Siberia for his revolutionary activities, but he escaped abroad by using a forged passport bearing the name Trotsky. Returning to Russia in 1905, he was again exiled, and again he escaped. Early in 1917 Trotsky went to New York City and became an editor of the Russian socialist paper Novy Mir (New World). After the revolution he returned to Russia and associated himself with Lenin, leader of the Bolshevik movement. When the Bolsheviks overthrew the provisional government, Trotsky became commissar of foreign affairs and later commissar of war. He organized the famous Red Army. After Lenin's death in 1924, Trotsky and Joseph Stalin struggled for leadership. Trotsky lost, and in 1928 he was exiled again. While living abroad he continued through his writings to fight Stalin's regime. In 1937 he sought refuge in Mexico. He was assassinated at his fortified villa near Mexico City in 1940.
TEXT.Polish: Lew Dawidowicz Trocki, w³aœc. Lew Dawidowicz Bronstein (ur. 7 listopada 1879 w Janówce, zm. 21 sierpnia 1940 w Meksyku)? rewolucjonista rosyjski, jeden z twórców i przywódców RFSRR i ZSRR. Przewodnicz¹cy Komitetu Wojskowo-Rewolucyjnego w Piotrogrodzie w czasie rewolucji paŸdziernikowej, cz³onek Biura Politycznego RKP(b) i WKP(b), komisarz ludowy spraw zagranicznych RFSRR, nastêpnie komisarz ludowy wojny i marynarki wojennej w rz¹dzie RFSRR i ZSRR (do 1925). Polityczny oponent Józefa Stalina, na jego rozkaz zamordowany.

TEXT.English: Truganini (c. 1812 - 8 May 1876) was a Aboriginal Tasmanian (Palawa). Truganini was born in 1812 on Bruny Island, located south of the Tasmanian capital Hobart and separated from the Tasmanian mainland by the D'Entrecasteaux Channel. She was a daughter of Mangana, Chief of the Bruny Island people. Her name was the word her tribe used to describe the grey saltbush Atriplex cinerea.
TEXT.French: Truganini (vers 1812 - 8 mai 1876) était une aborigène tasmanienne (Palawa). Née en 1812 sur l'île Bruny, au sud de la capitale tasmanienne Hobart, séparée du continent tasmanien par le détroit D'Entrecasteaux, elle était la fille de Mangana, chef du peuple de l'île Bruny. Son nom est le mot que sa tribu utilisait pour décrire le Buisson gris Atriplex cinerea.

TEXT.English: Trieu Thi Trinh is sometimes referred to as "the Vietnamese Joan of Arc." Like the even more famous Trung Sisters who preceded her, she was a woman-warrior and female general who is considered one of the great national heroes of Vietnam. She was a rebel leader at the time when Vietnam was a territory of China. She was orphaned as a young girl and she subsequently lived with her brother and his wife, who may have been Chinese, but was treated by them more like a slave than a relative. After a time, Trieu Au killed her sister-in-law and escaped to the hills where she raised an army of at least a thousand men and women. She and her army fought and won more than thirty major battles against the Chinese before she was twenty-one years old. She then set up her own administration in the freed territory which she kept independent for several months. When going to a battle, she lead her troops wearing a golden armor while riding an elephant and with a sword in each hand. The Chinese forces defeated her army in A.D. 248 but Trieu Au committed suicide by jumping into a river instead of surrendering. When her brother tried to discourage her military aspirations, she is believed to have said to him: "I will not resign myself to the lot of women, who bow their heads and become concubines. I wish to ride the tempest, tame the waves, kill the sharks. I have no desire to take abuse."
TEXT.Polish: Trieu Thi Trinh (znana tak¿e jako Trieu Au lub Ba Trieu), przywódczyni antychiñskiego powstania w Giao Chi w 248 r., bohaterka narodowa Wietnamu. Jej grób i œwi¹tynia (oen) znajduj¹ siê w Thanh Hoa. Od imienia Ba Trieu pochodzi nazwa powstania.

TEXT.English: In March 1898 the British started building a railway bridge over the Tsavo River in Kenya. The project was led by Lt. Col. John Henry Patterson. During the next nine months of construction, two maneless male Tsavo lions stalked the campsite, dragging Indian workers from their tents at night and devouring them. Crews tried to scare off the lions and built campfires and bomas, or thorn fences, around their camp for protection to keep the man-eaters out, to no avail; the lions leaped over or crawled through the thorn fences. After the new attacks, hundreds of workers fled from Tsavo, halting construction on the bridge. Patterson set traps and tried several times to ambush the lions at night from a tree. After repeated unsuccessful attempts, he shot the first lion on 9 December 1898. Twenty days later, the second lion was found and killed. The first lion killed measured nine feet, eight inches from nose to tip of tail. It took eight men to carry the carcass back to camp. The construction crew returned and finished the bridge in February 1899. The exact number of people killed by the lions is unclear. Patterson gave several figures, overall claiming that there were 135 victims.

Tuareg, Berber-speaking pastoralists who inhabit an area in North and West Africa. Tuareg society is traditionally feudal, ranging from nobles, through clergy, vassals, and artisans, to labourers (once slaves). The conventional Tuareg dwelling is a tent of red-dyed skin (sometimes replaced in the later 20th century with plastic). Traditional weapons include two-edged swords, sheathed daggers, iron lances, and leather shields.

The Tucano are a multilingual people because men must marry outside their language group; that is, no man may have a wife who speaks his language, for that kind of marriage relationship is not permitted and would be viewed as a kind of incest. Men choose the women they marry from various neighboring tribes who speak other languages. Furthermore, on marriage, women move into the men's households or longhouses. Consequently, in any village several languages are used: the language of the men; the various languages spoken by women who originate from different neighboring tribes; and a widespread regional 'trade' language. Children are born into this multilingual environment: the child's father speaks one language (considered the Tucano language), the child's mother another, and other women with whom the child has daily contact perhaps still others. However, everyone in the community is interested in language learning so most people can speak most of the languages. Multilingualism is taken for granted, and moving from one language to another in the course of a single conversation is very common. In fact, multilingualism is so usual that the Tucano are hardly conscious that they do speak different languages as they shift easily from one to another. They cannot readily tell an outsider how many languages they speak, and must be suitably prompted to enumerate which languages they speak and to describe how well they speak each one.

The Early Sican period began around AD 750 and lasted until 900. The lack of artifacts has limited the development of knowledge about this early period. The Sican were probably descendants of the Moche culture, which fell around AD 800. Their works shows shared motifs in the artifacts recovered. Similar groups include Cajamarca, Wari and Pachacamac. From remains found in the archaeological locations, researchers have determined that this culture maintained commercial exchange with people from present-day Ecuador (shells and snails), Colombia to the north (emeralds and amber), Chile to the south (blue stone), and the eastern basin of the Marañón River (seeds of gold). The Lambayeque culture may have been a separate trading people as well. Around AD 800 the Sican created the city of Poma, located at Batan Grande, in the La Leche Valley. Few other Early Sican sites have been discovered.

Mirza Tughai Bey was a notable military leader and politician of the Crimean Tatars. Tuhay Bey became the bey of Or Qapi (Or Bey) sometime between 1642 and 1644, an important position of the Crimean Khanate who was in charge of Or Qapi fortress - the gateway to the peninsula. By 1644 he had enough authority for the Khan of Crimea to entrust to him leadership of the major Tatar expedition against Poland. However, Tuhay Bey's army was intercepted by the Polish army under hetman Koniecpolski before reaching the densely populated regions of Ukraine and defeated in the First Battle of Okhmativ.

Tu'i-ta-tui was the 11th Tu'i Tonga, a dynasty of mighty kings in Tonga, and lived somewhere in the 12th century AD. If the number of stories told about him is an indication, then he was one of the mightiest kings of the dynasty for many generations before and after him. The Tongan Empire was one of the largest Polynesian empires in history, stretching over several island chains, and undoubtedly Tu'i-ta-tui contributed to its power. He was a great builder and leader.
TEXT.French: Tu'i-ta-tui était le 11ème Tu'i Tonga, une dynastie de puissants rois à Tonga, et a vécu vers le XIIe siècle. D'après le nombre d'histoires racontées sur lui, il fut l'un des rois les plus puissants de la dynastie sur plusieurs générations. L'Empire tongien était l'un des plus grands empires polynésiens de l'histoire, s'étendant sur plusieurs chaînes d'îles, et sans aucun doute, Tu'i-ta-tui contribua à sa puissance. Il fut un grand bâtisseur et chef.
TEXT.Polish: Tu'i-ta-tui by³ jedenastym królem Tu'i Tonga, z potê¿nej dynastii królów Tonga, ¿y³ oko³o 12-ego wieku n.e. Je¿eli iloœæ legend o nim mo¿e byæ jak¹œ wskazówk¹, to by³ najpotê¿niejszym królem wœród wielu pokoleñ przed nim i po nim. Ok. XII wieku Tongijczycy tworzyli siln¹ i znacz¹c¹ na terenie Pacyfiku cywilizacjê, okreœlan¹ przez niektórych historyków jako "Imperium Tongijskie" i z pewnoœci¹ by³a w tym i jego zas³uga.

TEXT.English: Tuoba Liwei was the first leader of the Tuoba clan of the Xianbei people, from 219-277.
